title: Hospitals in two-thirds of England face being closed or having services shut down
text:
Hospitals in two thirds of England's regions face being closed or having services shut (Photo: PA) Share Get politics updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
Hospitals face closure or having services such as A&E closed down in two-thirds of English regions. 
Plans to centralise NHS services and treat more patients in the community show 28 out of 44 include cuts to hospital services. 
They include everything from full closures to cutting specialist services, such as A&E and stroke care. 
Ministers argue patients will receive better care in the community, but experts warn of disaster unless drastic cuts to social care are reversed. 
Prof Chris Ham, of the King’s Fund, said care in the community is still the “best hope of delivering essential reforms”. 
But he insisted this could not be done without extra funding and urged the government to find the money to invest in community services. Ministers argue patients will receive better care in the community (Photo: Getty Images Europe) 
Prof Ham said: “Local plans must be considered on their merits but where a convincing case for change has been made, ministers and local politicians should back NHS leaders.” 
Some experts believe care needs to be moved out of hospitals due to an ageing population. It is argued that long-term conditions such as dementia and heart disease are better dealt with by keeping patients in their own homes. 
The plans will see maternity and children’s services in Lancashire “centralised” on to one site. 
Warnings were issued for West Yorkshire and Harrogate that five hyper-acute stroke service may “no longer be viable”. 
In Nottinghamshire they intend to significantly downsize City Hospital and reduce the number of beds across Nottingham by 200. 
According to the analysis by the BBC these changes will come alongside the creation of “super” community hubs of GPs, care workers and district nurses as well as seven-day access to GPs. 
Hospital specialists will run clinics in the community to bring care close to people’s homes. Hospital specialists will run clinics in the community 
A report by the King’s Fund warned community services are already “feeling the strain” and could not cope with an increase in workload. 
And the health think tank said slashing numbers of hospital beds further reductions could de-stabilise services already “stretched to their limits”. 
A spokeswoman for NHS England said: “They will allow the NHS to take advantage of new technologies, adopt successful practice more widely and make practical improvements in areas that we know matter most to patients. 
“These proposals are all about putting collaboration at the heart of our care system, with health and local government working more closely together than at any time since the NHS was created.” 
The proposals - known as sustainability and transformation plans - have been drawn up as part of NHS England’s five-year strategy to release £22 billion of efficiency savings by 2020. Health Secretary Jeremy Hunt (Photo: PA) 
Consultations on major changes will take place later this year with the hope implementation will follow soon after. 
But the King’s Fund warned the changes could be subject to legal challenges. 
The government is investing more money in the NHS, but a fund set up to pay for changing services has been swallowed up by deficits, figures released on Monday showed. 
A £1.8 billion pot set aside this year for funding transformation has been used to shore up NHS trust finances as they struggle to balance their books. 
The Department of Health insists extra money was being invested in the NHS this Parliament and gave the health service enough funds to change the way it worked. 
A spokesman said: “These NHS plans developed by local doctors, hospitals and councils working together with the communities they serve will help patients get better care.” Read More
